title: 110_hr2093
content: Disclosure of paid communications campaigns to influence the general public to lobby Congress. The amendments made by this section of the Lobbying Disclosure Act of 1995 apply only to lobbying firms representing clients, requiring registration and reporting. Definitions are updated to include paid communications campaigns aimed at influencing the public to lobby Congress. The Lobbying Disclosure Act of 1995 updates definitions to include paid communications campaigns by lobbying firms representing clients, with a threshold of $100,000 in quarterly spending. The Lobbying Disclosure Act of 1995 now includes paid communications campaigns by lobbying firms representing clients, with a spending threshold of $100,000 per quarter. The term 'paid communications campaigns to influence the general public to lobby Congress' refers to efforts by a lobbying firm to urge the public to contact officials to take specific action on certain matters. The Lobbying Disclosure Act of 1995 now covers paid communications campaigns by lobbying firms, excluding communications to clients and direct mail for recruiting members. Lobbying firms meeting certain criteria must register with the Secretary of the Senate and the Clerk of the House of Representatives within 45 days of being retained by a client. The Lobbying Disclosure Act of 1995 now includes paid communications campaigns by lobbying firms to influence the general public to lobby Congress. Amendments to the Act require separate itemization of income related to these campaigns. The Lobbying Disclosure Act of 1995 now includes paid communications campaigns by lobbying firms to influence the general public to lobby Congress. Amendments to the Act require separate itemization of income exceeding $50,000 from such campaigns.
